You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic

- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)

Paper Title: Size Should not Matter: Scale-invariant Stress Metrics

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
When computing a drawing of a graph, the positions of vertices are typically represented by Cartesian coordinates with respect to some abstract axes. There exists a large and diverse set of graph drawing algorithms, but they all differ in their treatment of coordinate units - some algorithms aim for unit-length edges¬†[ref]24, while others may treat vertices as objects with width in an nùëõn-body simulation¬†. It is intuitively understood by visualization designers that whatever units the output of a layout algorithm is, one must ‚Äúscale‚Äù (stretch or shrink) the coordinates of the vertices uniformly, so that it visually fits the desired computer window or canvas. However, when applying evaluation metrics to compare two or more algorithms, this difference in units may have a drastic, out-sized effect on the results. In the literature, this effect is typically glossed over in a few sentences¬†  if it is accounted for at all. The stress of the graph embedding aims to capture how well the graph distances are captured as Euclidean distances in the layout. Stress is the third most frequently used layout evaluation metric (after runtime and crossings) ¬†. While there are many stress variants, one of the most frequently used ones, Normalized Stress (N‚ÄãSùëÅùëÜNS)¬† [ref]24   , is severely affected by scale: Here, XisubscriptùëãùëñX_{i} and XjsubscriptùëãùëóX_{j} are the positions of vertices visubscriptùë£ùëñv_{i} and vertex vjsubscriptùë£ùëóv_{j}, di‚Äãjsubscriptùëëùëñùëód_{ij} is the length of the shortest path between them, and D={di‚Äãj|‚àÄvi,vj‚ààV}ùê∑conditional-setsubscriptùëëùëñùëófor-allsubscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë£ùëóùëâD=\{d_{ij}\;|\;\forall v_{i},v_{j}\in V\}.
The normalization factor di‚Äãj‚àí2superscriptsubscriptùëëùëñùëó2d_{ij}^{-2} balances the influence of short and long distances: the greater the graph-theoretic distance, the more tolerance we allow in the difference between the two distances. Despite the name and presence of this normalization factor, the N‚ÄãSùëÅùëÜNS metric is not normalized with respect to the scale of the positions of vertices, XùëãX, nor is it normalized to a range (which is unbounded). Fixing XùëãX and Dùê∑D as constants, we can observe the behavior of the function N‚ÄãS‚Äã(Œ±‚ÄãX,D)ùëÅùëÜùõºùëãùê∑NS(\alpha X,D) when varying the scaling factor Œ±>0ùõº0\alpha>0. Visually, there is no meaningful difference between drawings corresponding to different values of Œ±ùõº\alpha (e.g. Œ±=1,Œ±=2,formulae-sequenceùõº1ùõº2\alpha=1,\alpha=2, or Œ±=0.5ùõº0.5\alpha=0.5),
as this just uniformly scales the drawing up or down by Œ±ùõº\alpha.
Scaling by Œ±ùõº\alpha does not change the geometric relationship between the vertices at all, and is an implicit step one must take when performing graph visualization (e.g., to fit in a predefined window size).
However, as we can see from Figure¬†1, such scaling affects the value of N‚ÄãSùëÅùëÜNS drastically. This makes N‚ÄãSùëÅùëÜNS a poor measure to compare any two layout algorithms whose outputs might differ in scale. Further, when scale is not accounted for when comparing drawing algorithms, one cannot say where on the N‚ÄãSùëÅùëÜNS-scale plot a drawing might fall. In Figure¬†1, this amounts to picking any point on the blue line for Neato, any point on the red line for SFDP, and again any point on the green line for the random algorithm. By doing this, any desired order of the drawing algorithms could be obtained, either by accident or intentionally choosing desirable scale factors. Our Contributions:
In this paper, we begin by considering several stress-based graph layout metrics and the impact on the value when scaling the layout.
Notably, we show that the values of N‚ÄãSùëÅùëÜNS (and two other commonly used ones) change by orders of magnitude with even small changes in scale.
This creates a major obstacle to fairly comparing graph layouts obtained by different algorithms, which usually produce layouts at different scales. Specifically:
 We show that comparing stress values and not accounting for scale can result in clearly incorrect conclusions. We review 6 existing methods and propose 2 new ones for evaluating stress and experimentally verify them. We propose a ‚Äúgold standard‚Äù measure of stress, scale-normalized stress, that can be used to fairly compare the result of different graph layout algorithms. We provide open source implementations of all metrics, along with efficient computations thereof, as well as all the datasets, results, and analysis at our repository, https://github.com/JacobLMiller/graph-layout-metrics
